instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01700: What is 820-01700? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.TPS62180: What is TPS62180? This is a power chip responsible for many different power rails on 2016-2020 Macbook Pros,  most often known as the SSD buck converter chip responsible for NAND power rails.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> blown <CHIP>U9580</CHIP>
threads.message:
Hello everyone, have this board in and it already been verified by some one who found this chip is blown and removed it
Not sure what the original issue was.
Is there any point in trying to replace it or just scrap the board because ssd will be bad by now?


Any places to get this chip?

Thank you!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> blown <CHIP>U9580</CHIP>
threads.message:
Liquid spill on the video connector is the first cause.
Inspect for corrosion MLB connector and the one from T-CON also.

You can get <CHIP>U9850</CHIP> from scrap board, or Aliexpress.
[URL unfurl="true"]https://es.aliexpress.com/premium/CBTL06142EEE.html?d=y&origin=y&catId=0&initiative_id=SB_20220128004758&SearchText=CBTL06142EEE[/URL]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> blown <CHIP>U9580</CHIP>
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> blown <CHIP>U9580</CHIP>
threads.message:
Oooops, I got confused with <CHIP>U9850</CHIP>, sorry.

[URL unfurl="true"]https://es.aliexpress.com/af/<CHIP>TPS62180</CHIP>.html?d=y&origin=n&SearchText=<CHIP>TPS62180</CHIP>&catId=0&initiative_id=SB_20220128080813[/URL]
or scrap board, if available.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> blown <CHIP>U9580</CHIP>
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> blown <CHIP>U9580</CHIP>
threads.message:
Oh, forgot to mention:
L9580 and L9581 are shorted to ground...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> blown <CHIP>U9580</CHIP>
threads.message: If short persists after <CHIP>U9580</CHIP> is removed, then dead SSD...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> blown <CHIP>U9580</CHIP>
threads.message: Any ways to replace those ssd? Any ways to get them?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> blown <CHIP>U9580</CHIP>
threads.message:
Some people claimed on Internet they have changed the NANDs.
We have few threads about same question on the forum; nobody left a feedback about did it, or not.
